comment.description: Propose to add two new ARM entities based on AP210. Geometric_tolerance_arm Propose to add two new ARM entities based on AP210. ARM COMPOSITE_GROUP_SHAPE_ELEMENT A Composite_group_shape_element is a type of Composite_shape_element in which the composite may be thought of as a group of individual Shape_element in which any property that is applied to the Composite_group_shape_element is applied to each of the constituent Shape_elements on an individual basis. EXAMPLE: A group of cylindrical holes in a printed circuit board may be grouped with a Composite_group_shape_element for the purpose of applying the same Cylindricity_tolerance to each of the constituent holes in the group. Formal constraints: WR1: If all the Shape_elements that compose the Composite_group_shape_element are of the same type then the Composite_shape_element shall also be of that type. EXAMPLE: If all the Shape_elements that compose a Composite_group_shape_element are of type Centre_axis then, the Composite_group_shape_element will also be of type Centre_axis. mapped to AP210 entity composite_group_shape_aspect ?= composite_shape_aspect From AP210 A Composite_unit_shape_element is a type of Composite_shape_element that is treated as a unit, as opposed to as a group of individual Shape_element. EXAMPLES: A Profile_of_any_surface_tolerance is applied to a square cut-out that goes through a printed circuit board. The square cut-out is a Composite_unit_shape_element that consists of the four constituent Shape_elements that correspond to the four surfaces of the cut-out. A Flatness_tolerance may be applied to a Composite_unit_shape_element to specify that the coplanar surfaces that make up the Composite_unit_shape_element are required to fall within a common Tolerance_zone. NOTE: Common tolerance zones are described in 7.5 of ISO 1101. maps to: composite_unit_shape_aspect ?= composite_shape_aspect. "Accept GDT team will adopt 210 method and/or generalization of 214/224 machine features methods. Sean proposed that classification assignement could be used on the ARM and the mim so as to avoid creating new entities. This would be something of a departure for AP203."

ARM COMPOSITE_GROUP_SHAPE_ELEMENT A Composite_group_shape_element is a type of Composite_shape_element in which the composite may be thought of as a group of individual Shape_element in which any property that is applied to the Composite_group_shape_element is applied to each of the constituent Shape_elements on an individual basis.
EXAMPLE: A group of cylindrical holes in a printed circuit board may be grouped with a Composite_group_shape_element for the purpose of applying the same Cylindricity_tolerance to each of the constituent holes in the group. Formal constraints:
WR1: If all the Shape_elements that compose the Composite_group_shape_element are of the same type then the Composite_shape_element shall also be of that type.
EXAMPLE: If all the Shape_elements that compose a Composite_group_shape_element are of type Centre_axis then, the Composite_group_shape_element will also be of type Centre_axis.
mapped to AP210 entity
composite_group_shape_aspect ≨= composite_shape_aspect

From AP210 A Composite_unit_shape_element is a type of Composite_shape_element that is treated as a unit, as opposed to as a group of individual Shape_element. EXAMPLES:
A Profile_of_any_surface_tolerance is applied to a square cut-out that goes through a printed circuit board. The square cut-out is a Composite_unit_shape_element that consists of the four constituent Shape_elements that correspond to the four surfaces of the cut-out. A Flatness_tolerance may be applied to a Composite_unit_shape_element to specify that the coplanar surfaces that make up the Composite_unit_shape_element are required to fall within a common Tolerance_zone.
NOTE: Common tolerance zones are described in 7.5 of ISO 1101.
maps to:
composite_unit_shape_aspect ≨= composite_shape_aspect

issue.description: SC 4 shall not redefine concepts on geometrical product specification and tolerancing since they are already defined in ISO TC 213. Two examples:- Subclause 4.3.7 gives the definition of a "datum" which is different from the one of ISO 5459:1981 and also different from the one of ISO/DIS 5459-1:2002.- Subclause 4.3.4 defines a "compound_datum" which seems to correspond to a "common datum" in ISO 5459:1981 and ISO/DIS 5459-1:2002. A note has been added "A compound datum is in some tolerancing standards called a multiple datum feature or a common datum". SC 4 and ISO/TC 213 should work together to identify the discrepancies.

issue.description: BAE SYSTEMS has its own internal standards on tolerances, generally based on external standards such as BS8888. The propsed module will not be interpreted consistently unless it references an appropriate standard for Geometric Tolerancing. Observations marked MjT (Major Technical) may in fact be issues in the context of a particular tolerancing standard. It is therfore recommended that this module be REJECTED.

description.p: Agree this is needed. Not sure where is best place to put it. Probably high up the USE FROM tree, because potentially an external standard could apply to almost anything in an AP203e32 schema instance. I am thinking of annotations particularly which are not there but may come.
The only STEP standard that addresses this is AP210 which has an ARM entity mapped in part:

"requirements_property document_assigned_item <- applied_document_reference.items[i] applied_document_reference document_reference.assigned_document -> ee_specification document <- document_relationship {document_relationship document_relationship.description = `required specification'} -> ee_specification" dimensioning standard to be used for the interpretation of the GDT requirements. EE_SPECIFICATION "ee_specification <= document

EXAMPLE : document_name = "Technical drawings -- Geometrical tolerancing -- (etc) " creation_date.year = 1995 , publisher = "ISO" base_identifier = Ee_document_identifier assigned_value = identifier_name = "document number".

issue.description: Need to handle patterns of complicated shapes that may have different kinds of tolerances applied to different portions. Example: A rectangular hole with rounded corners.
